dialogues.text: Sexual innuendo connected with corporations... and ideologies that you assume you adopted through free will but are actually the result of hidden messages.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: What if there are messages that aren't subliminal, but are meant only for certain people?

dialogues.speaker: COMIC MAN
dialogues.text: Of course. That's as common as tits and hamburgers.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: COMIC MAN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Comic man pulls a wooden panel away from the wall, reveal dark crawl space. Dusty boxes are visible at the head of the narrow passage On one of the boxes, sits a surveillance monitor connecte an old VCR. Comic Man leans over and crawls into the secret opening, disappearing into the darkness. Sam looks at the surveillance monitor and VCR. He sees a VIEW of the living room, the backdoor and the side of the house nearest the garage.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: What's with the cameras?

dialogues.speaker: COMIC MAN
dialogues.text: I'm trying to protect myself. Do you know how many people have died from the Owl's Kiss?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: No. I don't. Sam looks around at Comic Man's bedroom. He glances at th ACTION FIGURES and the SKETCHES charting the stages of th moon. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: COMIC MAN
dialogues.text: I got the place wired up... nobody gets in here without me knowin' Right? Sam says nothing. He waits - looking into the dark crawl space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahhh. Here it is. Comic Man crawls back into the light, waving a CEREAL BOX triumphantly.

dialogues.speaker: COMIC MAN
dialogues.text: Got it. Got it. Got it. Comic Man climbs out and shows Sam the box of MOONSTONES cereal from the mid 70's. He spins it around and points a East Los Angeles map on the back of the box. Giant letters announce: Treasure Hunt! Fun Prizes! Sam studies the colorful map. Cartoon characters poke the heads out of famous east side locations. Griffith Park Observatory, etc...

dialogues.speaker: COMIC MAN
dialogues.text: I bought this from another collector five years ago. I'm convinced that this map is the key to everything I've been searching for my whole life.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Seriously?

dialogues.speaker: COMIC MAN
dialogues.text: Seriously. Sam points to the Contest Card on the side of the box - l with fine print.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I think all you had to do was mark down where the characters are hiding and send in your contest card. Here. Comic Man sighs. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: COMIC MAN
dialogues.text: It's not about Moonstone toys. This map is geographically to scale. From Silverlake to the Hollywood Hills. It's guiding me somewhere important and one of these days I'll crack it. Comic Man stares at Sam with a sweaty and strained face. Sam avoids eye contact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam passes scooter girls and fedora men as he soaks throu his shirt - melting in the heat. He glances back, looking at the hipsters and homeless men the sidewalk behind him. They are all wearing similar hat

dialogues.speaker: HOMELESS MAN
dialogues.text: Anybody spare some change? Please? Sam divides and steps through an enormous line extending from the local Intelligentsia Coffee - all parties standi a long red carpet that ends at the Sunset gutter. Everyone seems to know each other. A long line of feigned surprise and big smiles.

dialogues.speaker: PRETTY WOMAN
dialogues.text: Oh my gosh, honey, what are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER PRETTY WOMAN
dialogues.text: Just grabbing an afternoon coffee.

dialogues.speaker: SMUG MAN
dialogues.text: Hey! Good to see you... And on and on. Sam keeps walking. Everyone is beautiful... or at least very, very interesti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Griffith Park Observatory is visible high above on the hillside. Sam crosses a picturesque bridge, staring at the pretty houses. He looks around, glancing back at the empty street.  50 61.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam walks up the sidewalk and sees Bar Buddy smoking and drinking on his porch. Seeing Sam, he waves and approache meeting in the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: BAR BUDDY
dialogues.text: Where's your car?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Oh. It's in the shop. Getting repainted from all that graffiti.

dialogues.speaker: BAR BUDDY
dialogues.text: That's what you get for driving that cockmobile.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I like my car.

dialogues.speaker: BAR BUDDY
dialogues.text: I like my cock. I don't have to compensate for it. Sam ignores his friend, shaking his head.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Did you hear about Jefferson Sevence?

dialogues.speaker: BAR BUDDY
dialogues.text: Yeah they found him dead in his car last night. With three prostitutes and a dog.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Yeah I think Sarah was one of the prostitutes. The dog was the same breed as hers and I saw her hat ina crime scene bag on the news.

dialogues.speaker: BAR BUDDY
dialogues.text: Fuck. I'm sorry, man.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Thanks. I feel weird accepting condolences. I barely knew her.

dialogues.speaker: BAR BUDDY
dialogues.text: You liked her though.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Mm hm. A little bit. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BAR BUDDY
dialogues.text: So what are you gonna do now?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I kinda wanna find out who killed her

dialogues.speaker: BAR BUDDY
dialogues.text: Isn't that a little... serious?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I guess so. What else am I gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: BAR BUDDY
dialogues.text: I don't know. The two men chuckle to one another. Bar Buddy changes the subject.

dialogues.speaker: BAR BUDDY
dialogues.text: Wanna see something cool?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Yeah. What is it?

dialogues.speaker: BAR BUDDY
dialogues.text: You gotta check out my drone. Bar Buddy points his thumb towards the backyard.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Your what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A medium-sized DRONE rises up from the center of the back Silent like some future monster. Its rotors spin. The black quadcopter houses a state of the art camera sys The two men sit on the grass, in front of a laptop - whic rests on a cheap folding chair. Their heads are tilted cl Beers in hand. Sam watches the drone hover and soar through the neighbor Disappearing into the black sky. Bar Buddy operates the controls from his laptop - pilotin drone.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Shit. Where do you get something like this? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BAR BUDDY
dialogues.text: I got it on amazon.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Hm. POGO, Bar Buddy's golden retriever walks up to Sam throug grass. The dog licks his hand and arm. Sam pulls away - a fake s forming. Bar Buddy notices and tugs gently on his dog's collar.

dialogues.speaker: BAR BUDDY
dialogues.text: Leave him alone, Pogo. Come here. Pogo steps away. Bar Buddy rubs the dog's head, petting h fondly. Sam relaxes.

dialogues.speaker: BAR BUDDY
dialogues.text: Look at that. Silverlake from above. The drone soars over Los Angeles. Transmitting a blur of lights, houses, cars and streets. Bar Buddy sniffs the air. Something is afoul. He smells P fur.

dialogues.speaker: BAR BUDDY
dialogues.text: Jesus, what's that smell?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: It's me.

dialogues.speaker: BAR BUDDY
dialogues.text: Oh. Bar Buddy accepts the fact with a casual nod. He taps some buttons, watching the drone's camera-relay n to the computer's mapping system. The drone settles in place. Bar Buddy focuses the camera on a large window overlookin canyon - some modern home in the hills.

dialogues.speaker: BAR BUDDY
dialogues.text: Ok. This is a good one. I've been scouting houses and I think this chick used to be in lingerie commercials. Amazing body. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The drone's camera shows an empty, but bright living room Well decorated.

dialogues.speaker: BAR BUDDY
dialogues.text: Gotta be patient. Bar Buddy taps the edge of the chair in anticipation.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You ever feel like you fucked up somewhere a long time ago and you're living the wrong life? Or a bad version of the life you were supposed to have?

dialogues.speaker: BAR BUDDY
dialogues.text: You're fine.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: No. I used to think I was gonna be someone that other people cared about. Maybe do something important...

dialogues.speaker: BAR BUDDY
dialogues.text: Shit. Everybody thinks that, but the world can't support it. Somebody has to sweep the floor. This fucked up idea that life owes us a god damn good story is a bunch of crap. We're not all special and we're certainly not equal. That's the biggest lie ever Bar Buddy looks at Sam - sees his beaten expression. Understands it. He puts his hand on Sam's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: BAR BUDDY
dialogues.text: Everyone thinks they're going to be famous. Narcissism and entitlement

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Look where we live. Bar Buddy and Sam look out into the night air. The cricke chirp. The wind blows through the trees.

dialogues.speaker: BAR BUDDY
dialogues.text: It feels like there's something darker under the surface. Waiting to come out. Do you ever feel like that?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Yeah... I think somebody's following me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BAR BUDDY
dialogues.text: Probably. Bar Buddy smiles and starts to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: BAR BUDDY
dialogues.text: Who isn't being followed nowadays? Sam laughs along with his friend.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: No, but I feel like that a lot. Even before all this craziness.

dialogues.speaker: BAR BUDDY
dialogues.text: It's the modern persecution complex. Who needs witches and werewolves anymore, now that we have computers? Everyone is suffering from mild paranoia. I don't think our fuckin' monkey brains are comfortable knowing that they're interlinked and routed together like some all knowing human brain. This shit causes delusion and fear, but we don't see it because we're too busy playing "Angry Birds".

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: BAR BUDDY
dialogues.text: Persecution Complex is just the opposite side of the spectrum from the Privilege Complex. It's basically the dark mirror of our dreams and aspirations. You think you're special and that secrets and blessings have been planted in the world for you. The schizophrenic thinks that people are out to get them and that there's a hidden and dangerous world below the surface. These two paths are more similar than anyone wants to admit. Persecution complex is the modern plague. It's the universe balancing things out. Two nearly middle-aged men in undersized t-shirts sitting the grass in a dark backyard drinking beer and huddling b a small monitor... Sam leans in towards the screen - taking note of the empt room. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Doesn't seem like she's home.

dialogues.speaker: BAR BUDDY
dialogues.text: Everyone on the planet thinks that they're somehow the "chosen one". But they're also afraid the world might be out to get 'em. It's the nature of things anymore. It's modern technology, it's saturation of pop culture, it's living in a world where ten years olds can become singing superstars from their bedrooms.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Yeah, but those kids have real success. Real money. It is possible to get lucky and achieve a dream. Doesn't that go against your whole thesis?

dialogues.speaker: BAR BUDDY
dialogues.text: No way. Who cares if five or ten people catch a break? That's like winning a golden ticket into Wonka- land. It's appeasement. It's fantasy. It's the stuff dreams are made of On the screen, they see a CHESTY WOMAN walk into the room takes her shirt off, revealing her bra. They watch in sil as she sits down in a chair and starts to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bar Buddy moves the controller, turning the drone's camer away from the sad woman's window.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I'm gonna take off. I'll see ya soon.

dialogues.speaker: BAR BUDDY
dialogues.text: Be careful out there. Sam leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam walks toward the cemetery entrance. Hipsters carry cheese plates, blankets and wine through t iron gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam walks alone down a grave-lined path. The air has cooled... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Pretty young women walk through the cemetery in their sum clothes. Orchestral score echoes - as though performed through a loudspeaker. Dialogue from a film soundtrack carries across the gravey Source unseen. We hear reverb-filled voices. Much like the hollow sounds heard when stepping into the back of a large movie theate mid-screening. As Sam steps over the hill, he sees hundreds of people si on the grass before a make-shift movie screen. A film is projected onto the back wall of a mausoleum. Picnic blankets and lawn chairs fill the space. Sam steps to the rear of the crowd, and watches the film. A quiet scene in some suburban backyard. A young mid-west girl smokes a cigarette and flirts with a teenage boy. He friend watches from a lawn chair opposite her. The pixie with the Seberg-haircut flashes a star-making smile. Sam looks through the crowd. No one familiar. He makes his way toward a tree-lined path, glancing back the film. Onscreen, a pig-tailed teen girl frowns while talking to boyfriend. Sad but photogenic eyes. Her soft voice echos across the graveyard. Sam notices a man with a diamond grill smoking pot with t pretty young women. He has his arms around them like trop They lean together against a thick-stump tombstone.

dialogues.speaker: DIAMOND GRILL
dialogues.text: (laughing in distance) Two for one month, right? Walking closer along the path, Sam recognizes them. It's the two girls from the movie. Older now, but recogni the same. A regular pair of SHOOTING STARS. Their hair is styled exactly as it is in the film being s tonight. Their attire is nearly inappropriate - like some hipster variations on Jodie Foster's wardrobe from Taxi Driver. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Hey. You're the girls. In the movie. SHOOTING STAR #2 flips a pig tail over her shoulder and t a puff from the joint.

dialogues.speaker: SHOOTING STAR
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: SHOOTING STAR
dialogues.text: That's us. The girls smile and stare at Sam through stoned eyes. DIAMOND GRILL ignores him, smoking his joint and touching girls' faces.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: SHOOTING STAR
dialogues.text: Thank you. SHOOTING STAR #1 smiles and nods, looking down at the gro with a shy shuffle. Her short Seberg-hair catches the lig

dialogues.speaker: SHOOTING STAR
dialogues.text: Do you like the movie?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Um... yeah... I just got here, but I'm sure it's... Shooting Star #2 notices a scent wafting by. She sniffs t air - interrupting.

dialogues.speaker: SHOOTING STAR
dialogues.text: Gosh, do ya smell that? Sam takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: SHOOTING STAR
dialogues.text: Smells like skunks and... pot The Seberg-girl displays an exaggerated grimace. Too pout a grown woman.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Los Angeles is filled with skunks. Especially the east side.

dialogues.speaker: DIAMOND GRILL
dialogues.text: We should get going. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SHOOTING STAR
dialogues.text: Ok. Diamond Grill leads them toward a limousine, parked along inner drive. They stumble in their heels, under the influ Sam watches them climb inside, slumping together across leather seats. Light music emanates. A man's head peeks out from within the dark limo. It's the Hipster Pirate. Sam reacts - taking a step close The door shuts. Slam! The limousine accelerates down the cemetery road, disappe around the corner. Behind Sam, on the mausoleum wall, the short haired girl smiles and flirts with a small town boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam walks up to a TUXEDO BOUNCER standing before a roped- doorway. Potted plants and Saint statues flank the edges this marble entrance. An elegantly designed cardboard floor-sign announces: Summertime Secret Show! The rumble of music can be heard from inside. Sam holds up his cookie invitation. Tuxedo Bouncer examin and nods his head. He eyes Sam with displeasure.

dialogues.speaker: TUXEDO BOUNCER
dialogues.text: You gotta take a bite before I can let you in. Sam looks at the bouncer's face. He's quite serious. Sam shrugs and shoves the entire cookie in his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam makes his way through a deep crowd, milling about wit the large mausoleum hall. Waitresses carry drinks and hor d'oeuvres to the young and fashionable crowd. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Looking over heads and shoulders, Sam sees the small stag near a row of shrines. Spotlights illuminate the main attraction. Meek Bride stands on the stage, dressed in her 20's gown 80's tennis shoes. She leans forward and speaks quietly into the microphone a cute mouse - nervously pressing her dress down onto her knees.

dialogues.speaker: MEEK BRIDE
dialogues.text: Thank you everybody for being here. I want to dedicate this first song to the man who taught me everything I know. This song is for Jesus. The small piece orchestra sitting in the shadows of the s begin to play. A sad and slow version of a famous tune. To Sir With Love...

dialogues.speaker: MEEK BRIDE
dialogues.text: (singing) Those schoolgirl days of telling tales and biting nails are gone. But in my mind I know they will still live on and on... The men in the room watch with wistful eyes and deep long Sam watches the Bride perform, simultaneously eyeing the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: MEEK BRIDE
dialogues.text: (singing) But how do you thank someone who has taken you from crayons to perfume? It isn't easy, but I'll try... Sam hears a woman's voice behind him...

dialogues.speaker: RECORD GIRL
dialogues.text: Records?... Records?... Records? Sam turns and sees RECORD GIRL handing out sample albums the party-goers. Record Girl wears a 1930's cigarette gir outfit - carrying a wooden tray filled with double stacke of the newest Jesus and the Brides of Dracula single. She straight out of Cocoanut Grove. The girl holds her tray of records out before Sam - offer him one. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RECORD GIRL
dialogues.text: Records? Sam takes one and looks at the cover, smiling quickly to girl.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Thank you. On stage, Meek Bride continues to sing like a sad angel.

dialogues.speaker: MEEK BRIDE
dialogues.text: (singing) If you wanted the sky, I would write across the sky in letters that would soar a thousand feet high.... to sir with looooove... Making his way to the bar, Sam notices his friend Allen chatting with a cute bartender. He walks up and shakes th man's hand.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: How's it going?

dialogues.speaker: ALLEN
dialogues.text: Work is good. Floatin' along. You know.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Yeah. I get it. Sam signals the bartender. She leans in.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (to bartender) Jack on the rocks, please.

dialogues.speaker: ALLEN
dialogues.text: You find those girls you were lookin' for?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: No. Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: ALLEN
dialogues.text: I'll keep an eye out. Three hot girls in a rabbit. Sam smiles and nods. He passes some cash to the bartender sips his drink. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Um... have you noticed anything strange going on in this whole circle of friends? Anything out of the ordinary?

dialogues.speaker: ALLEN
dialogues.text: That's kind of everyday, right?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: No. I know. I mean... extra strange.

dialogues.speaker: ALLEN
dialogues.text: Last week, this girl I hooked up with... she was fucked up out of her mind... said some weird stuff about Jesus and the Brides.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Like what? Allen looks around, then leans in close to Sam.

dialogues.speaker: ALLEN
dialogues.text: That there's a message in the music. Allen grins, tapping his finger on the record in Sam's ha Sam glances at the sleeve. Jesus and the Brides pose toge like a post-modern perfume ad.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Like a secret message? Allen smiles, laughing about the idea.

dialogues.speaker: ALLEN
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: What's it say?

dialogues.speaker: ALLEN
dialogues.text: I don't have a clue, man.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Who's this girl?

dialogues.speaker: ALLEN
dialogues.text: Just one of the many. You know.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Right. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALLEN
dialogues.text: Crazy makes for good sex. Remember that. Allen looks Sam in the eye, smiles and pats him on the shoulder. He notices a group of mustachioed muscular men in mesh sh passing by. Allen waves and smiles, stepping away from Sa engage his friends in a series of complicated hand shakes man hugs. Sam watches Allen disappear into the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: MEEK BRIDE
dialogues.text: (singing) I would rather you let me give my heart... to sir with looooove... Balloon Girl bumps against Sam, wearing an Italian-chic s dress with sandals - looking like an object of infatuatio from an old Rohmer film from the mid 70's. She leans against the bar - her bare shoulder touching Sa arm. He looks at her face.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I hardly recognized you without your balloons. Balloon girl shakes her head with a small grin.

dialogues.speaker: BALLOON GIRL
dialogues.text: You saw that?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Uh huh. The pretty girl points at the drink in Sam's hand.

dialogues.speaker: BALLOON GIRL
dialogues.text: Would you buy me one?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Sure. Sam looks to the bartender

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: One more.

dialogues.speaker: BALLOON GIRL
dialogues.text: Thanks. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sam pulls the final twenty dollar bill from his wallet an pays for the drink. Balloon Girl smells something funny, but says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Can I ask you a question?

dialogues.speaker: BALLOON GIRL
dialogues.text: Yeah. Sam shows Balloon Girl his photo of Sarah, setting it dow the bar.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Did you ever see her around? Balloon Girl nods her head. Yup.

dialogues.speaker: BALLOON GIRL
dialogues.text: Sarah.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You know what happened to her? Sam hands Balloon Girl her whiskey. She takes a drink.

dialogues.speaker: BALLOON GIRL
dialogues.text: Come with me. Balloon Girl grabs Sam's hand and pulls him through the c

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: BALLOON GIRL
dialogues.text: The basement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Balloon Girl hops down the stone steps, dragging Sam behi her.

dialogues.speaker: BALLOON GIRL
dialogues.text: It's "old music night" at the crypt club. She reaches a thick wooden door and knocks hard against i tiny slot opens, revealing a peering eye.

dialogues.speaker: DOOR GUARD
dialogues.text: What's the password? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BALLOON GIRL
dialogues.text: Tricycle Bicycle. The door opens and Balloon Girl pulls Sam into the dark r

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cigarette smoke fills the cavernous crypt club. Rough sto walls, curtained booths, and tombstone tables surround th dance floor. Music thumps as the crowd hops and sways to a classic pop tune. Something recognizable from the 1990's. Sam and Balloon Girl are sitting together at one of the t - their drinks and elbows resting on a perfect replica of Jayne Mansfield's tombstone. The pair share a cigarette - taking turns with their drag They shout over the painfully loud music. Conversing!

dialogues.speaker: BALLOON GIRL
dialogues.text: (looking at Sarah's photo) I didn't know her very well, but she was around! I saw her at parties and shows and stuff! I don't know what happened to her, but I can tell you it didn't have anything to do with my friends! We're just enjoying our world, enjoying our bodies, enjoying our music... ! Sam holds up his 45 record, displaying the cover of Jesus the Brides. He points to it as he talks.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I heard people saying that there's some kind of code or secret message in their music! Balloon Girl laughs.

dialogues.speaker: BALLOON GIRL
dialogues.text: I'm pretty sure that's not true! Jesus wouldn't hide a message in a message! Sam says nothing as he nods. He takes a drag of his cigar Ballon girl slides the photo across the table to him.

dialogues.speaker: BALLOON GIRL
dialogues.text: There's nothing to solve, you know?! It's silly to put so much energy into something that doesn't matter! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Balloon Girl reaches into her dress and pulls out a piece flaccid red rubber. She holds the balloon up to her mouth blows into it.

dialogues.speaker: BALLOON GIRL
dialogues.text: We have this tiny window where we can have fun and fuck and and be free... ! Tying it off with her fingers, the girl raises up the inf balloon and moves her cigarette closer and closer to it.

dialogues.speaker: BALLOON GIRL
dialogues.text: Life is too short, right?! Balloon Girl presses the cigarette against the rubber, po the balloon in her hand. She smiles to Sam. Sam takes a gulp of his drink, eyeing Balloon Girl with curiosity. A powerful and loud power chord blasts from the club's speakers. It's REM's "What's the Frequency Kenneth".

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Come on! I wanna dance to this!

dialogues.speaker: BALLOON GIRL
dialogues.text: I don't know this song!

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Come on! On the dance floor, under the strobing lights, the pair b to feel the music. The energy of it.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (singing along! ) I'd studied your cartoons, radio, music, TV, movies, magazines... Richard said, "Withdrawal in disgust is not the same as apathy"... Sam dances wildly to the song - a giant grin rarely seen the context of this story. He dances, jumps and swings hi arms like a whirling and mad Michael Stipe. The girl laug joyfully along with Sam.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (singing along) "What's the frequency, Kenneth?" is your Benzedrine, uh-huh... (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: SAM (cont'd) Butterfly decal, rear-view mirror dogging the scene... You smile like the cartoon, tooth for a tooth... You said that irony was the shackles of youth... Sam dances and stares into the girl's beautiful but young face. She moves to the beat... though clearly unfamiliar the tune or the lyrics he's chanting. Sam is the only one singing along, but he doesn't care. They are separated by age and the ever shifting tectonic plates of pop culture. The dance floor is half full. Most of the crowd sways cas and cool. Sam and Balloon Girl smile and jump, shaking al with the heavily tremoloed chords - using their power to remain unique and alive.

dialogues.speaker: BALLOON GIRL
dialogues.text: We should fuck!

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Yes! Sam's world grows large. The crowd twists and transforms. Color stretches into unbelievable hues. Sam grabs his face. Rubs his eyes. His legs grow weak. He turns and staggers off the dance floor. Balloon Girl follows.

dialogues.speaker: BALLOON GIRL
dialogues.text: What's wrong?!

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I feel really strange!

dialogues.speaker: BALLOON GIRL
dialogues.text: How much of the cookie did you eat?!

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: The whole thing!

dialogues.speaker: BALLOON GIRL
dialogues.text: Shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam vomits into the toilet. Loud and terrible.  59 60 61 78.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam walks out of the bathroom - dizzy. He holds his head nauseous and pale - as he scans the crowd. His table is e Balloon Girl is gone.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Fuck me. Near the entrance, he sees Troy, one of the Rabbit conver girls. As he steps closer, focusing his eyes, Troy spots him and pushes through the crowd - rushing out the door. Sam foll picking up the pace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

His breathing intensifies. Sweat everywhere. He gets closer and closer, staring ahead at the girl spri along in her jean shorts. Everything starts to slow down... turning purple... then black... Sam falls to the ground - holding his head. Darkness.

dialogues.speaker: SAM

Their clothes and outfits are identical matc to several of the outfits worn by the young women and men this same place the night before. All these old hats and colorful slacks... utility over fashion... fashion over utility... utility over fashion...

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Oh good. I just thought it would be something nice to share. She's soooo lovely. I feel connected to her. Is that silly?

dialogues.speaker: MOM

dialogues.text: I love you too.

dialogues.speaker: MOM

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Bye. (CONTINUED)

Janet Gaynor 1906-1984 Sam sees an empty beer bottle sitting atop the gravestone stares at it, shaking his head. Sam pulls himself up, grabs the bottle and throws it angr into the far-off trees. Wait for it... A tiny and soft sound - the crush of glass in the distanc

dialogues.text: the surface... Sam scribbles the lyrics down on an empty tomato-stained box with a black sharpie marker.

dialogues.text: Sam and Bar Buddy sit in front of the television playing Mario Bros on the 8-bit Nintendo. Sam is flipping through stack of old Nintendo Power Magazines - reading about che and tips. They are eating a fresh pizza from Tomato Pie.

dialogues.text: I just remember sitting in my room, and making up my own weird little codes and secret language... it felt like there was so much mystery in the world... things to be figured out and solved... The friend nods. He understands and relates.

Modern Man needs mystery. We need to believe that there's something worth finding. On screen, Sam's Mario sinks down into a secret green sew pipe - accompanied by a sound effect - the sound of disco

dialogues.speaker: BAR BUDDY

A naked Penny Baker from 1984... A submerged and nude Carol Willis from 1970... A modern supermodel in a purple bra... A sardonic hippy chick in tight red jeans... Sarah in her white hat... Mrs. Sevence and Millicent, crying on the cover of People A giant breasted porn star... Continuing to pleasure himself, Sam flips the pages of th Weekly to the smut section in the back of the paper. Strippers and whores. Phone numbers for escorts and sex c Sam notices a quarter page advertisement featuring the sm faces of several pretty young women. Different than the average stripper or sex ad. Sam looks down at the girls' faces. He's seen these girls before. Very short hair on one. Pigtails on the other It's the two Shooting Star girls from the cemetery movie. They check our ID's, we just wander the streets of this luxury neighborhood... walking into whatever house we want, whatever room we want. There's food everywhere. Music. Dancers. Craziness. It was this big open party, like straight outta Gatsby.
